    • Method Detail

      • newPooledBuffer

        public static Buffer newPooledBuffer(int sizeMode)
        Returns a Buffer that has been allocated for the specified sizeMode. The following is a table of the different possible sizeMode combinations.
        Size Mode 0 1 2 (default)
        Buffer Capacity 100 5,000 30,000
        Parameters:
        sizeMode - the sizeMode used to determine the type of buffer to retrieve
        Returns:
        a lazily-allocated Buffer

      • putOpcode

        public void putOpcode(int opcode)
        Puts the specified opcode as a packet opcode in this buffer. This function takes the next integer produced by the ISAACCipher and adds it to the specified opcode. This, in effect, encrypts the opcode to make it more difficult to sniff out actual packet opcodes. It is the server's responsibility to have correctly setup their receiving ISAACCipher to mimic the results of this sending ISAACCipher.
        Parameters:
        opcode - the opcode of the packet

      • put

        public void put(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as an 8 bit data-type. The value written is just an 8 bit data-type. Therefore only the low 8 bits are significant.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putShort

        public void putShort(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as a 16 bit data-type. The value written is just a 16 bit data-type. Therefore only the lower 16 bits are significant.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putLEShort

        public void putLEShort(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as a 16 bit data-type in Little Endian order. The value written is just a 16 bit data-type. Therefore only the lower 16 bits are significant. Little Endian is a byte order where the value is written into the buffer from least-significant byte to most-significant byte.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • put24BitInt

        public void put24BitInt(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as a 24 bit data-type. The value written is just a 24 bit data-type. Therefore only the lower 24 bits are significant.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putInt

        public void putInt(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as a 32 bit data-type.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putLEInt

        public void putLEInt(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as a 32 bit data-type in Little Endian order. Little Endian is a byte order where the value is written into the buffer from least-significant byte to most-significant byte.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putLong

        public void putLong(long value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying buffer as a 64 bit data-type.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putString

        public void putString(java.lang.String value)
        /** Places the specified String ino the underlying buffer. The String written into the buffer with each character representing a single 8 bit value. The end of the String is signified by the value 10.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the buffer

      • putBytes

        public void putBytes(byte[] src,
                     int offset,
                     int length)
        Places the specified byte[] into the underlying buffer starting at offset and writing length bytes.
        Parameters:
        src - the byte[] to insert into this buffer
        offset - the offset to start reading from src
        length - the number of bytes to insert

      • getString

        public java.lang.String getString()
        A String is read from the underlying buffer by reading in bytes until a byte with the value '10' is read. Once this value is read, the byte[] is then turned into a new String.
        Returns:
        the next string read from the underlying buffer.

      • getStringAsBytes

        public byte[] getStringAsBytes()
        Returns:
        a String that has been converted into a byte[].
        See Also:
        getString()

      • getBytes

        public void getBytes(byte[] out,
                     int offset,
                     int length)
        Read length bytes from the underlying buffer, putting the result in out starting at index offset.
        Parameters:
        out - the byte[] to write the data in
        offset - the offset to start writing in the byte[]
        length - the amount of bytes to put into the byte[]

      • initBitAccess

        public void initBitAccess()
        Initialize bit access in this Buffer. This function sets the bitOffset to the current offset multiplied by 8.

      • getBits

        public int getBits(int size)
        Parameters:
        size -
        Returns:

      • finishBitAccess

        public void finishBitAccess()
        Finalize bit access. This function just sets the current byte offset to bitOffset divided by 8. If the resulting calculation is a decimal, then it always rounds to the next number.

      • getSmartA

        public int getSmartA()
        Read either an unsigned 8-bit data-type or an unsigned 16-bit data-type. This function peeks at the next unsigned byte stored in the buffer. If that value is less than 128, the value is calculated to be 64 subtracted from the initial unsigned byte read. If the initial unsigned byte read is greater-than or equals-to 128, the result is 49152 subtracted from the next unsigned 16-bit data-type read from the stream.
        Returns:
        the value received

      • getSmartB

        public int getSmartB()
        This function is similar to getSmartA() except the values will be returned with different arithmetic applied. If the initial byte is less than 128, the unsigned byte is returned. If the initial byte is greather-than or equal-to 128, the value is 32768 subtracted from the next 16-bit data type received.
        Returns:
        the value received
        See Also:
        getSmartA()

      • applyRSA

        public void applyRSA(java.math.BigInteger exponent,
                     java.math.BigInteger modulus)
        Applies the RSA algorithm to the underlying byte[].
        Parameters:
        exponent - the public exponent for the RSA encryption
        modulus - the modulus for the RSA encryption

      • putByteC

        public void putByteC(int value)
        Places the value into the underlying byte[]. The value is negated before being placed into the byte[].
        Parameters:
        value - the value to place into the byte[]

      • putByteS

        public void putByteS(int value)
        Places the value into the underlying byte[]. The value is subtracted from 128 before being placed into the byte[].
        Parameters:
        value - he value to place into the byte[]

      • getUnsignedByteA

        public int getUnsignedByteA()
        Returns:
        128 subtracted from the next byte received from the byte[] represented between the values 0 and 255.

      • getUnsignedByteC

        public int getUnsignedByteC()
        Returns:
        the inverse of the next byte received from the byte[] represented between the values 0 and 255.

      • getUnsignedByteS

        public int getUnsignedByteS()
        Returns:
        the next byte received from the byte[] subtracted from 128 represented between the values 0 and 255.

      • getByteC

        public byte getByteC()
        Returns:
        the inverse of the next byte received from the byte[]

      • getByteS

        public byte getByteS()
        Returns:
        the next byte received from the byte[] subtracted from 128

      • putShortA

        public void putShortA(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying byte[]. The 16-bit data-type that is placed into the underlying byte[] is transformed by having 128 added to the lowest-order byte.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to be placed into the byte[].

      • putLEShortA

        public void putLEShortA(int value)
        Places the specified value into the underlying byte[]. The 16-bit data-type that is placed into the underlying byte[] is transformed by having 128 added to the lowest-order byte written in Little Endian order.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to be placed into the byte[].

      • getUnsignedShortA

        public int getUnsignedShortA()
        Returns:
        the next unsigned 16-bit data-type read from the underlying buffer transformed by substracting 128 from the lowest-order byte.

      • getUnsignedLEShortA

        public int getUnsignedLEShortA()
        Returns:
        the next unsigned 16-bit data-type read from the underlying buffer transformed by substracting 128 from the lowest-order byte read in Little Endian order.

      • getLEShort

        public int getLEShort()
        Returns:
        the next 16-bit data-type read from the underlying buffer in Little Endian order.

      • getLEShortA

        public int getLEShortA()
        Returns:
        the next 16-bit data-type read from the underlying byte[] in Little Endian order transformed by subtracted 128 from the lowest-order byte.

      • getInt2

        public int getInt2()
        Returns:
        the next 32-bit data-typed read from the underlying (@code byte[]) in a Mixed Endian order.

      • getInt1

        public int getInt1()
        Returns:
        the next 32-bit data-typed read from the underlying (@code byte[]) in a Mixed Endian order.

      • putBytesA

        public void putBytesA(byte[] src,
                      int offset,
                      int length)
        Places length bytes from src into the underlying byte[] starting at offset. Each byte is trasformed by having 128 added to it.
        Parameters:
        src - the byte[] to insert into the underlying byte[]
        offset - the offset to begin reading from src
        length - the number of bytes to place

      • getBytesReversed

        public void getBytesReversed(byte[] src,
                             int offset,
                             int length)
        Reads bytes from the underlying byte[]. This function places the values read from the underlying byte[] into src in a reverse order, so the first byte read from the underlying byte[] is the last byte that's placed in to src.
        Parameters:
        src - the byte[] to place the data in
        offset - the offset to start writing to inside of src
        length - the amount of bytes to read
